Award.AbstractNarration:
The workshop "Simulating QCD on Lefschetz thimbles" will be held between June 28 and June 30, 2017, at the European Centre for Theoretical Studies in Nuclear Physics and Related Areas (ECT*). This workshop will bring together researchers in the area of Lattice Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD) to study a promising new approach to solving QCD on the lattice that is expected to alleviate deficiencies of current methods. Developing reliable methods of calculating the properties of QCD is important, because QCD is the theory of strong interactions that binds fundamental particles known as quarks and gluons into protons and neutrons, the building blocks of atomic nuclei. If successful, the new approach will have significant impact on the experimental program at the Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider (RHIC) at Brookhaven National Laboratory.

This workshop represents a good opportunity for junior researchers to further their training and improve their careers. To make this possible, NSF funding will provide partial travel support for junior scientists, graduate students and postdoctoral fellows, to attend this workshop. The focus of this activity on new methods to solving Lattice QCD at finite density is expected to improve the understanding of experiments at relativistic ion colliders that study the quark-gluon plasma properties and the location of the QCD critical point.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the workshop was to bring together a set of researchers of international repute to discuss results and new alternatives in applying the method of Lefschets thimbles to the computational approach to many-body quantum systems. Leading physicists from Japan, Europe and the United States met at the Center for Nuclear Physics (ECT*) in Trento, Italy. The ECT* provided logistic support and some of the funding.

 

About 15 formal talks were presented followed by extensive discussions. The NSF contribution allowed that American students and postdocs to participate in the Workshop. The exposure of the students to the international community of practioners in this field helped foster their careers and allowed them to acquire skills that are currently being used in their research. 

 

The scientific outcome of the Workshop can be mainly described in two points. First, it was established that systematic comparison between versions of the method applied to the same physical models should be made in order to benchmark results that can then be used in further code development. Second, some particularly interesting physical problems where the Lefshets thimble method can be applied were identified. These physical systems will serve as a steppinng stone to be used in order to achieve the final goal of applying the thimble method to QCD and nuclear physics. This ultimate goal is of central importance to both the development of Nuclear Science in the United States as well as to the more practical goal of stockpile stewardship.
